declarations.comments:
This module provides some very simple representations of HTML fields.
Don't look for single sum type or Variant which ties all of them.

Fields represantation is as minimal as possible, so only
validation relevant pieces are exposed as attrs.
declarations.title: Input

declarations.comments:
This field can be used to represent for example multiple checkboxes with the same
`name` or `select multiple` - it's final value is record with all elements
being Booleans.

Result type for `MultiChoice` field can be statically and generically generated
by helpers from `Field.Generic`, so you can use sum type or "Symbol list" which
(`Variant` stripped down to just a label) is implemented in `Field.Generic.Option` module.

If you provide type like:

 `data Choices = C1 | C2 | C3`

 or

 type Choices = "C1" :- "C2" :- Nil

You can expect something like this as a result of validation
(derived from `Field.Generic.multiChoiceParser`):

  { C1 ∷ Boolean
  , C2 ∷ Boolean
  , C3 ∷ Boolean
  }


Of course you can provide your own representation for choices like list of `Strings` etc.
declarations.title: MultiChoice

declarations.comments:
This type class provides basic way to transform simple sum type
(constructors without args are only allowed) into: `Validation` and
`choices` array which can be used in `Choice` record.
declarations.title: SingleChoice

children.comments:
This function doesn't report
invalid values (hence Unit as error type)
It only marks valid ones currently...
children.title: multiChoiceParserImpl

declarations.comments:
"Custom sum" type (heavly inspired by (or ripped from) purescript-variant internals)
which allows you to easily provide options (together with order)
for you Choice/Multichoice fields "without" defining dedicated type.
declarations.title: Nil

declarations.comments: `Option` is our symbol list carrier
declarations.title: Option

declarations.comments:
NumberInput can be used to represent
`type="range"` and `type="number"`
of Integer values
declarations.title: IntInputErr

declarations.comments:
I'm not sure if this `type ∷ SProxy` attribute
is really good idea.
If you find it problematic please fill an issue.
declarations.title: NumberInputBase

declarations.comments:
All these input types share same attributes... but email.
Email has additional "multiple" attribute
but this will be handled by separate field for handling list of
emails.
declarations.title: EmailInput

declarations.comments:
These helpers seems rather useful only
in case of field validation scenarios
so they are here.
declarations.title: check

declarations.comments:
Tiny wrapper around validation which also
carries default "form" value.
declarations.title: Component

declarations.comments:
Simple helper which combines basic pieces into `Component`:
 - form constructor (I could use `Applicative.pure` but it seems a bit to heavy constraint ;-))
 - default field value
 - validation
declarations.title: fromField

declarations.comments:
Longer version of previous one which
allows coersion of field level value
into form level value.
declarations.title: fromFieldCoerce

declarations.comments:
WARNING!
It is still prototyping phase
of this module.
declarations.title: FieldErr

declarations.comments: Val is a self reference to an object
declarations.title: ArrayField

declarations.comments:
You should wrap this array into
your constructors which represent
some type of object.
declarations.title: Attrs

declarations.comments: `Attr` wraps other field and attaches attribute name to it
declarations.title: AttrErr

declarations.comments:
You should define your fields using something
like:

data MyField
  = IntField (IntField ())
  | StringField (StringField ())
  | NumberField (NumberField ())
  | Object (Attrs MyField)

What is really imporant is that `Attrs` wrapper should be recursive.
declarations.title: attr

declarations.comments:
This representation should cover all
possible http query values:
`?field`, `?field=`,
`?field=value`,
`?field=value1&field=value2`
declarations.title: Value

declarations.comments: XXX: Drop this "coerce" version
declarations.title: fromFieldCoerce

declarations.comments:
This representation should cover
possible http query values:
`?field`, `?field=`, `?field=value`,
`?field=value1&field=value2`
declarations.title: Value

children.comments:
This instance uses first valid value and accumulates only in case of invalid
results.

pure (Valid e1 a1) <|> pure (Invalid e2) = Valid (e1 <> e2) a1
pure (Valid e1 a1) <|> pure (Valid e2 a2) = Valid (e1 <> e2) a1
pure (Invalid e1) <|> pure (Invalid e2) = Invalid (e1 <> e2)

If you need "dual" strategy just use apply which "prefers" invalid results:

pure (Valid e1 a1) *> pure (Invalid e2) = Invalid (e1 <> e2)
pure (Invalid e1) *> pure (Valid e2 a2) = Invalid (e1 <> e2)
pure (Valid e1 a1) *> pure (Valid e2 a2) = Valid (e1 <> e2) a2

If you find any not accumulative instance useful please
add a newtype wrapper and provide a PR with related tests.

And maybe there is also a place for
"`Alt` somewhat dual to our `Category`"
which short circuits on the first valid result...
children.title: altV

children.comments:
Defaul `Semigroup` instance appends valid and invalid
parts of our `V`.
children.title: semigroupV

declarations.comments:
Provides access to validation result
so you can `bimap` over `e` and `b` type in resulting `V e b`.
declarations.title: BifunctorValidation

declarations.comments:
As we are not able to provide `Parallel` instance currently
(https://github.com/purescript/purescript-parallel/issues/24)
here we have some synonims.
declarations.title: parallel
